thread.title: Ducks, Huskies push 'rivalry' significance to the side: Oregon rundown
thread.title_full: Ducks, Huskies push 'rivalry' significance to the side: Oregon rundown | OregonLive.com

author: Andrew Greif | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Ducks, Huskies push 'rivalry' significance to the side: Oregon rundown
text:
The Oregon Ducks don't trot out their "every game is a Super Bowl" line that often anymore, but the timing is right for Saturday's matchup against Washington in Seattle.
Considering this game could be critical to both teams' hopes of going to any bowl, period, this is a big one.
Which is why neither team is framing the 7:30 p.m. kickoff as a meeting of rivals, so much as a meeting of two teams searching for consistency.
"They need to focus on technique and execution and confidence and that happens by having a great Tuesday," coach Mark Helfrich said of the Ducks (3-3, 1-2 Pac-12), who are under .500 in conference play through three games for the first time since 2003.
"Not worried about what happened in 1978. That's not to discount 1978, I'm sure it was a great year — but we have to improve right now."
Washington leads the series 58-44-5 and Helfrich, the Oregon native, noted he "absolutely" knows the meaning of a rivalry that, after a one-sided stretch of Huskies domination — UW won 12 of 13 against UO from 1974 to 1986 — was stoked into a more competitive series in the mid-1990s.
"I think you educate guys on the rivalry as we have so many guys from around the country that don't, Quote: -unQuote: , get it," Helfrich said. "But on a weekly basis we don't talk about the opponent too much in that regard."
Helfrich isn't alone in downplaying any long-simmering angst between the programs, the majority of whose players don't come from the states they play in: Oregon holds an 11-game winning streak in the series, a stretch of success underscored Tuesday by Huskies defensive backs coach Jimmy Lake.
UW's Lake on Oregon rivalry: "Hopefully we can make it a rivalry. Because it hasn't been for the last decade."
— Adam Jude (@A_Jude) October 13, 2015
